p.s: The text on hand is an excerpt from The Hate U Give, a book written by Angie Thomas.
In the excerpt Starr visits a demonstration against Khalil's murder and police Brutalitybrutality.
The excerpt can be labledlabelled in 3 sections.
In the first section Starr, Chris, Seven and DeVante arrive at the demonstration.
The surroundings are described and Seven, DeVante and Chris join in with the A hairbrush is not a gun chant.
In the next section Starr lives through the moment where Khalil was killed again in her mind.
When it comes to the part where Khalil got shot she cuts out and screams the chant as loud as she can.
A narrative technique was used here to make readers relate to Starr (ll. 18-22).
After she stots that, Ms. Ofrah noticed her and drives over to her to speak with her.
After talking about how she wants to do something (l. 30) Ms. Ofrah hands her the bullhorn.
The third section now begins and now she lets out everything she has in mind.
It doesn't start like this immediately though, at first she stutters a little and cannot talk straight.
It is only when the police said You need to leave immediately she snapped and thought to herself You know what?Fuck it. (l. 48).

While this line may be considered unnecessary and too vulgar it is nevertheless a great way her point of view was used to stress that she doesn't care what others think anymore and wants to seize her opportunity and to say everythin she ever wanted people to know about Khalil.

During her speech there is another point where an insight to her thoughts are given (ll. 57f), in which she described how speaking in front of the crowd gives her this positive speaker happy feeling, using colloquial language, this causes another effect to make reader identify with Starr because young people tend to speak this way.
In conclusion I would say the author does a good job in making readers relate with the protagonist of the book.
It is also great to see how Starr, who actually didn't want to speak out and rather not say anything now completely changed her mind.
